metadata.title: LAND, LABOR, AND LOVE: Household Arrangements in Nineteenth Century Eastern Finland-Cultural Heritage or Socio-Economic Structure?
metadata.journal_or_publisher: The History of the Family An International Quarterly

relevance.topic: Household arrangements and socio-economic structures in 19th century Eastern Finland
relevance.relevance: The study examines the transformation of household structures in response to economic changes, particularly the shift from slash-and-burn to set-field agriculture, which reduced the need for large workforces and influenced family and labor dynamics.

design.sample_characteristics: The study focuses on the parish of Virolahti in the province of Viborg, Eastern Finland, examining household structures and socio-economic changes.

independent_variables: shift from slash-and-burn to set-field agriculture

key_themes: impact of agricultural practices on labor needs
text_fragments: The absence of serfdom and corvée labor linked household size and economic needs more directly with ecology and resources.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes how joint-family households were replaced by stem families as the need for a large workforce diminished with the replacement of slash-and-burn agriculture with set-field agriculture.

technological_changes: replacement of slash-and-burn agriculture with set-field agriculture
historical_context.economic_conditions: Transition from an economy reliant on slash-and-burn agriculture to one based on set-field agriculture and cattle raising.
historical_context.institutional_context: The absence of serfdom and corvée labor in Finland, unlike in neighboring Russia, influenced household and economic structures.

outcomes.main_findings: The study found that economic factors, particularly the shift from slash-and-burn to set-field agriculture, were more influential than cultural factors in determining household structures in Eastern Finland.
outcomes.conclusions: Economic changes, rather than cultural influences, were the primary drivers of changes in household structures in 19th century Eastern Finland.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The transformation of household structures from joint-family to stem families reduced the capacity for large family units to support the old and young, leading to increased landlessness and social change.
